sub_topic: Prove that the intersection of two sets is a subset of each of the sets.
message_1: Let A = {1, 3, 5, 7} and B = {3, 7, 9, 11}. Using set theory, prove that the intersection of sets A and B is a subset of each of the sets.
message_2:
To prove that the intersection of sets A and B is a subset of each of the sets, we need to show that every element in the intersection of A and B is also an element of A and B.

The intersection of sets A and B, denoted as A ∩ B, is the set of all elements that are common to both A and B. In this case, A ∩ B = {3, 7}.

Now, let's take an arbitrary element x from the intersection A ∩ B. We have two possibilities for x: x = 3 or x = 7.

1) If x = 3, then x is an element of A (since 3 is in A) and x is an element of B (since 3 is in B).

2) If x = 7, then x is an element of A (since 7 is in A) and x is an element of B (since 7 is in B).

In both cases, x is an element of A and B. Therefore, every element in the intersection A ∩ B is also an element of A and B.

Thus, we can conclude that the intersection of sets A and B, A ∩ B, is a subset of each of the sets A and B.
